I suppose that we're used to these strange one-off animals being basal members of their family trees (eg coelacanths look like fish of near a 380 million years ago and lemurs look more like the primates of 55 million years ago); if an animal is unique it usually looks more like its ancestors than it's other modern relatives. With the echidna it looks like the basal mammal of 400 ma ago didn't just stay still, but evolved orthogonally to all the other mammals. It's just as different from our common ancestor as we are but in a completely different direction.
Nature is absolutely bananas :)

The description of the reproductive 'birthing process' sounds like something transitional between the ovivipariousness in some reptiles and the marsupium of marsupials but without teats.  Which I was under the impression that the monotremes were always sort of nested as diverging before marsupials and placental mammals; so it would make sense since a lot of their traits (weak endothermy, the lack of specialized external mammary anatomy, egg hatches into a pseudo-marsupium) feel in-between that of the more oviparous reptiles and the more modern 'mammals'.

Serious question...


I know that the definition of a mammal is that the female has mammary glands that feed the young with a nutritious milk. And that's why monotremes are defined as mammals.
But what is the definition of a bird or a reptile?


As far as I am aware, there are no proper definitions of birds and reptiles.
But if there would be any such a definition of birds, then I guess it would be that birds have feathers. I believe that all birds have feathers, and that no species that are not birds have feathers.
Also, I believe that reptiles have a special bone that is unique to them, and that no other species have. I don't remember what this special bone is called, or where it is.


The interesting thing (again, if I recall correctly), is that monotremes also have this unique reptile bone. Also, monotremes do not have hair, as was said in this video. They have feathers.


So that would make monotremes both mammal, reptile, and birds.

The extant species off Echidnas are all native to New Guinea.  Are you sure about this Australian thing?

Also about Echidnas - the common ancestor of Platypuses and Echidnas was headed towards the water a long time before the whales, but the Echidnas, after branching off, headed back towards land. Perhaps that was the specific environmental change that caused the speciation.  The Platypus, for whatever reason, stayed a small freshwater species, while the whale grew in size and eventually managed to enter salt water, so that the Basilosaurus could be found from Georgia (USA) to Egypt.

Lies! Echidnas have stomach... no acid in it, but still:
"The echidna's stomach is quite different from other mammals. It is devoid of secretory glands and has cornified stratified epithelium, which resembles horny skin.[45] Unlike other mammals, which typically have highly acidic stomachs, the echidna has low levels of acidity, almost neutral, with pH in the 6.2–7.4 range.[45] The stomach is elastic, and the gastric peristalsis grinds soil particulates and shredded insects together"

Considering the extreme diversity of mammals and other mammal like synapsids that developed in the past and left marks on the fossil record(even if typically fragmentary) with significant mammalian diversity in forms and adaptations the better question is probably not "why are they so weird" but why did they survive when most mammals met the same fate as the nonavian dinosaurs they shared the earth with for hundreds of millions of years.

The survival of the Echidna Platypus as well as marsupials is likely no coincidence as for some reason it seems many "ancient" mesozoic life forms that went extinct in the northern hemisphere were somehow able to persist into the cenozoic on the isolated fragments of ancient gondwana including plants such as monkey puzzle trees seed ferns(up to the Eocene) monotremes and Tuataras among others.

It may be coincidence but it feels fishy to me for it only to be coincidence... I do have to wonder whether the absence of placental mammals played a role as well...
